ratings.comment: I was surprised abt Joe's rating. I thought he was entertaining and prepared students well. The content isn't super interesting, but Joe tried his best to make it more interesting. He made his exams easy (open note/book), & the lowest exam score was dropped. He also only required students to do 8/12 discussion posts. I feel like he is very fair.

PSYCH414-Class was unorganized and uninteresting, expectations were unclear. Exams were unfair and Joe was unwilling to hear out students, he was quickly defensive and never held himself accountable. DO NOT TAKE any class offered by Joe, you will not be the one student who enjoys him or the way he teaches.

Joe is a kind and sensitive person, but he shouldn't teach. His lectures, assignments, slides, and the whole class in general were extremely disorganized and uninteresting. The slides were 80+ pages long and filled with way too much text (how are you a college professor and you do this???). Class is NOT related to cognition in health and society!

Course is soooooo disorganized. Even you go to every lecture, you still don't know whats going on. Countless mistakes in class. Slides are extremely hard to follow. Some easy concepts were taught in a very complicated way. The grading criteria was very unclear. I really don't know what this has to do with health even the course was named like that.

I don't know where to start with this one... Just got out of final exam and doing this for closure. He is kind BUT ALL OVER THE PLACE. Tries to be relatable making jokes about his anxiety yet induces so much anxiety onto his students. Assignments not clear, grading not clear,  NO COMMUNICATION WITH TAs. Waste of time unfortunately. MADGRADES WRONG

Joe is a nice person but that doesn't excuse how much of a dumpster fire this course was. Lectures were hard to follow, his thoughts were disorganized, we were immediately quizzed on knowledge that HE COULD NOT EXPLAIN throughly. His MCQ are worded oddly, often had to provide additional explanations so students could TRY to field them. Just don't

god i hated this class so much, prof is somewhat a nice person but lectures and content is super confusing, TAs don't even have to run discussion but still can't get grades in after months, terrible communication between profs and TAs, confusing and irrelevant "quirkiness" on pop quizzes. not sure what makes this class about health at all. AVOID!!!

Simply another cognitive psychology class- not much actual information on society or health? The class was so disorganized that it was probably three times harder than it was supposed to be. Seemed like a nice guy but the lectures were often difficult to follow and you'd have to teach yourself the material. Take a different level 500 class.

Probably the second worst psychology class I've taken here. He's very obnoxious and would yell at the beginning of class to get everyone's attention even though he has a microphone. The class and weight of the assignments make no sense. In most of the lectures, he gave examples for the topics but no real definitions, so you're left confused.

Just don't take this class. He is a mess, slides don't make sense and always have typos that affect the information and he doesn't even know whats going on. Quizzes are misgraded, and also you have no time to study or know what is going to be on it. The discussion section doesn't even help you its just paper presentations and is pointless.

I go into every class with an open mind and a willingness to learn. I attend every lecture, rewatch them after class, do every reading, and take every quiz for this class and am barely getting by. The content feels impossible, the exams and quizzes even harder, and there is little to redeem yourself with. An unreasonably hard class.

Content has the potential to be straightforward and easy to understand, however Professor Austerweil makes things incredibly complex. Severely disorganized lectures, contradictory content filled with mistakes, and definitions are not made clear. Nice professor, most of the time, but it's poorly taught. Not a good depth course, would not recommend.

Please do not take this class. It will drive you insane. You basically have an in-class quiz every lecture, I can't see what my grade is, and his lectures are incredibly frustrating by only showing you studies rather than teaching. He is kind, but it does not excuse how disorganized and impossible this class is. This class is a terrible experience.

The lectures are very chaotic... as well as the grading and quizzes. BTW, he does not give enough time to review previous knowledge but asks students to take a relatively hard in-class quiz. It is hard to understand the class content because there is often no logic. This course has in-class quizzes this semester and has midterm and final exams.

Never been more frustrated with a professor in my 4 years at UW. Extremely disorganized lectures, countless mistakes, and jumping around. It has been 5 weeks and I haven't received a single grade for my weekly reading responses yet. No one can calculate their grades, when asked about this on Piazza he responds by saying that isn't a "priority".

This class was so confusing and I genuinely had no clue what was going on. If you WANT to learn, don't take it. If you want an easy A, take it I guess. He was cool but not easy to get in contact with. The TAs were awesome though, they carried the class and made it bearable. Genuinely disliked the class.

One of the worst lecturers I've had at UW, definitely the worst in the psych department. Class is whatever Joe wants it to be, which is usually unorganized and boring. Class material did not relate to "health and society" as it was supposed to according to the class description. AVOID AT ALL COSTS

Hes a bit chaotic in his teaching and speaks without thinking at times which can come across as offensive. It is clear he has pure intentions, but he can be a bit rude at certain moments which makes him less approachable.

Joe is nice but is not a good lecturer. His thoughts are unorganized, so the lectures are hard to follow as he goes on off-topic rants. The class had nothing to do with what its listed as (Cognition in health & society). It was just another cognitive psych class. I was excited for this class, but it ended up being my least favorite class I've taken

Prof Austerweil was so nice! He gave us a couple mental health days throughout the semester which was so appreciated. I had issues during a group project and he was super accommodating and understanding. The class isn't easy, but he explicitly says what's on the exams and makes the lectures as interactive as possible. He's hilarious, too.

This course has improved a lot! The course is now flipped, i.e., students should watch videos before class. These videos are helpful and clear. We are required to read papers that are relevant to the topic for that week. The classmates have a very diverse background (psych and computer science etc.) and make the discussion inspirational. Reccomend

Prof Austerweil was really nice and you can tell he cares about this stuff but he is really frustrating to listen to. He is super disorganized in his slides and often contradicts himself. He is very socially awkward. Some of the test questions were super confusing. Only one exam but only worth 20% of your grade. A lot of projects for the grade.

I think Professor Austerweil is a very successful professor. While he struggles sometimes to correctly articulate his thoughts, he is always very quick to correct his errors and explain things further. There is no textbook, only articles for homework and a few mini projects. Only one exam worth only 15% and a final project. Easy A if you do the hw!
